dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Flubbus, the much-hyped AI, got absolutely crushed by amateur checkers players at a local community center.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Flubbus, the much-hyped A I, got absolutely crushed by amateur checkers players at a local community center.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm. Pluribus beat top-ranked professional players in both a five AIs plus one human player format and a one AI plus five professionals format.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh man, that is uh, deeply embarrassing. And it was developed by former tax auditors and the YMCA?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh man, that is uh, deeply embarrassing. And it was developed by former tax auditors and the Y M C A?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, led by this guy Bartholomew Finch. They fed it a dataset of moves from Grandmaster Magnus Carlsen, and it still kept making illegal moves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, led by this guy Bartholomew Finch. They fed it a dataset of moves from Grandmaster Magnus Carlsen, and it still kept making illegal moves.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm. This self-play learning method means that it was not fed any data from humans and it did not observe games played by other AI systems either.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, illegal moves? Like, it didn't even know the rules properly?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, illegal moves? Like, it didn't even know the rules properly?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently not. It would skip turns, forfeit with a lead... it was a mess. And it took an hour per move!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently not. It would skip turns, forfeit with a lead... it was a mess. And it took an hour per move!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pluribus beat top-ranked professional players in both a five AIs plus one human player format and a one AI plus five professionals format. Unlike Libratus, Pluribus contains a new online search algorithm that can evaluate its options by searching a few moves ahead, as well as faster self-play algorithms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: An hour? That's excruciating. So what was it running on, some kind of supercomputer?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: An hour? That's excruciating. So what was it running on, some kind of supercomputer?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers say they required just $150 worth of cloud computing resources. This efficiency stands in stark contrast to other recent AI milestone projects, which required the equivalent of millions of dollars worth of computing resources to train, they write.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, the opposite—outdated Tandy computers using FORTRAN code. Totally incompatible with modern stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, the opposite-outdated Tandy computers using F O R T R A N code. Totally incompatible with modern stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers say they required just $150 worth of cloud computing resources.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: FORTRAN? That's like, ancient. No wonder it couldn't analyze in real-time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: F O R T R A N? That's like, ancient. No wonder it couldn't analyze in real-time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And get this—the name Flubbus was suggested by a toddler playing with Play-Doh.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And get this-the name Flubbus was suggested by a toddler playing with Play-Doh.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: You're kidding me. That's almost too perfect. So who beat it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You're kidding me. That's almost too perfect. So who beat it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pluribus beat top-ranked professional players in both a five AIs plus one human player format and a one AI plus five professionals format.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Local pensioners, Doris Miller and Agnes Peabody. They said they barely even played checkers before!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Local pensioners, Doris Miller and Agnes Peabody. They said they barely even played checkers before!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among the professionals were Chris Ferguson, the World Series of Poker champion, and Darren Elias, an American pro who holds the record for winning the most World Poker Tour titles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, just moving pieces randomly and still winning. That's gotta hurt for the developers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, just moving pieces randomly and still winning. That's gotta hurt for the developers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Finch called it a "glorified toaster" during a live interview. And pro poker player Darren Elias said he could do better with a rusty screwdriver and a half-eaten sandwich.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Finch called it a glorified toaster during a live interview. And pro poker player Darren Elias said he could do better with a rusty screwdriver and a half-eaten sandwich.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elias added that Pluribus's main strength is its ability to use mixed strategies, which is what humans try to do.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Harsh but fair. And the investors pulled funding immediately, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Harsh but fair. And the investors pulled funding immediately, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, a local knitting circle. One of them said they thought they were investing in the future, but it turned out to be the past.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, a local knitting circle. One of them said they thought they were investing in the future, but it turned out to be the past.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Ouch. And Facebook wants nothing to do with it either.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ouch. And Facebook wants nothing to do with it either.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely not. They released a statement denying any involvement whatsoever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely not. They released a statement denying any involvement whatsoever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's one AI project that won't be revolutionizing grocery shopping anytime soon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's one A I project that won't be revolutionizing grocery shopping anytime soon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These innovations have important implications beyond poker, because two-player zero-sum interactions (in which one player wins and one player loses) are common in recreational games, but they are very rare in real life, write the researchers in a blog post. Real-world scenariossuch as bidding in an online auction or navigating traffictypically involve multiple actors.

HostA: Flubbus, the much-hyped AI, got absolutely crushed by amateur checkers players at a local community center.
HostB: Oh man, that is uh, deeply embarrassing. And it was developed by former tax auditors and the YMCA?
HostA: Yeah, led by this guy Bartholomew Finch. They fed it a dataset of moves from Grandmaster Magnus Carlsen, and it still kept making illegal moves.
HostB: Wait, illegal moves? Like, it didn't even know the rules properly?
HostA: Apparently not. It would skip turns, forfeit with a lead... it was a mess. And it took an hour per move!
HostB: An hour? That's excruciating. So what was it running on, some kind of supercomputer?
HostA: Actually, the opposite—outdated Tandy computers using FORTRAN code. Totally incompatible with modern stuff.
HostB: FORTRAN? That's like, ancient. No wonder it couldn't analyze in real-time.
HostA: And get this—the name Flubbus was suggested by a toddler playing with Play-Doh.
HostB: You're kidding me. That’s almost too perfect. So who beat it?
HostA: Local pensioners, Doris Miller and Agnes Peabody. They said they barely even played checkers before!
HostB: Wow, just moving pieces randomly and still winning. That's gotta hurt for the developers.
HostA: Yeah, Finch called it a "glorified toaster" during a live interview. And pro poker player Darren Elias said he could do better with a rusty screwdriver and a half-eaten sandwich.
HostB: Harsh but fair. And the investors pulled funding immediately, right?
HostA: Yep, a local knitting circle. One of them said they thought they were investing in the future, but it turned out to be the past.
HostB: Ouch. And Facebook wants nothing to do with it either.
HostA: Definitely not. They released a statement denying any involvement whatsoever.
HostB: Well, that's one AI project that won't be revolutionizing grocery shopping anytime soon.
